row.entry: These rules provide for the implementation of a system for the issue, filing and service of court documents by electronic communication. They establish a procedure for registration of electronic users. UCPR Sch 4 sets out the kinds of documents to which the ECM system applies. The ECM system may be used for proceedings that can be conducted in the absence of the public.
This Part applies to all courts in CPA Sch 1: see UCPR r 1.5 and Sch 1 .

These rules are new and complement Electronic Transactions Act 2000 Part 2A and Sch 1 . That legislation permits the Attorney-General to establish an Electronic Case Management system for use in particular courts.
Business in the absence of the public ‥ [r 3.9]
Filing by use of ECM system ‥ [r 3.4]
Wills — electronic filing in probate proceedings ‥ [r 3.6]

p.text: In this Part:
means an electronic case management system established under clause 2 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000.
means a person who is registered as a user of the ECM system under rule 3.3 .
[subr (1) am Amendment 38 of 2010 s 3(1), effective 15 October 2010]
In this Part, a reference to filing a document in the court includes a reference to any other method of sending a document to the court.
This Part applies to those courts, and for those purposes, for which the use of an ECM system is authorised by an order in force under clause 3 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000.
[r 3.2 am Amendment 38 of 2010 s 3(2), effective 15 October 2010]
Legislation cited in [3.2.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Electronic Transactions Act 2000 Clause 2, Sch 1 cl 3.

Clause 2 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000 Sch 1 cl 2 (previously s 14B) authorises the establishment of an electronic case management system. Under Sch 1 cl 3 (previously s 14C), the Attorney-General may, by order published in the Gazette, authorise the use of an ECM system by such courts and for such purposes, as are specified in the order.

The registrar of the court may register any person as a user of the ECM system in relation to the court, either generally or for particular proceedings, and may specify the level of access to which the person is entitled, and the conditions of use applicable to the person, as a registered user of the system.
Subject to any order of the court, a person may not be registered as a user of the ECM system for particular proceedings unless the person is:
a party to the proceedings, or
a legal practitioner representing a party to the proceedings, or
a person authorised to use the ECM system in relation to the proceedings by a legal practitioner representing a party to the proceedings, or

a person who, pursuant to rule 4.4(1)(b) or 4.4(3), is authorised to sign documents on behalf of a party in proceedings in the Local Court, but only in connection with proceedings and matters in relation to which that paragraph or subrule authorises documents to be so signed.
[subrule (2) am Amendment 26 of 2009 Sch 1[1], effective 8 May 2009 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
The senior judicial officer of the court may establish a protocol for the registration of persons as users of the ECM system, either generally or for particular proceedings.

Such a protocol may provide for the automatic registration of particular classes of persons as users of the ECM system, and for the automatic specification of the level of access to which persons of such a class are entitled and the conditions of use applicable to persons of such a class as registered users of the system.
In relation to any proceedings before the court, the level of access to the
ECM system to which a registered user is entitled, and the conditions of use applicable to a registered user, are subject to any order of the court.

The court can order legal representatives to apply to the Registrar for registration of themselves and any person authorised by them as users of the ECM system: Hill v W & F Lechner Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 440; BC200603298 (failure of defendant’s solicitor to cause counsel for the defendant to become registered as user of ECM system after repeated requests from judge’s associate — order requiring registration, potential cost consequences for defendant’s solicitor).
This rule applies:
in relation to proceedings in any court other than the Land and Environment Court, to documents of a kind referred to in Part 1 of Schedule 4, and
in relation to proceedings in the Land and Environment Court, to documents of a kind referred to in Part 2 of Schedule 4.
[subr (1) subst Amendment 20 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[1], effective 28 January 2008]
In any proceedings, a document so specified may be filed in the court on behalf of a party, by means of the ECM system, by any registered user for the proceedings who is:
a person who is authorised by rule 4.4 to sign documents on the party’s behalf, or
a person who has been directed to file the document by a person who is so authorised.
[subr (2) subst Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 30 September 2005]
When filed by means of the ECM system, a document that is required to be signed by a person is taken:
to have been duly signed for the purposes of rule 4.4 , and
to have been duly authenticated for the purposes of clause 5 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000,
if the person’s name is printed where his or her signature would otherwise appear.
[subr (2A) insrt Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 30 September 2005 ; am Amendment 38 of 2010 s 3(3), effective 15 October 2010]

A document that is filed by means of the ECM system is to be given initial acceptance as soon as it is received by the court, and is to be given final acceptance as soon as it is validated by the court.

Without limiting any other ground on which it may be refused, validation is to be refused if any fee payable with respect to the filing of a document is not received by the court within 24 hours after the document’s initial acceptance.

A document that is filed by means of the ECM system is taken to have been filed when it is given final acceptance and, when given final acceptance, is taken to have been filed at the time it was given initial acceptance.
Notice of the initial and final acceptance of a document, and of the dates of those acceptances, is to be given, by means of the ECM system, to the registered user by whom the document was filed.
The date and time at which initial or final acceptance was given must be set out in the notice referred to in subrule (6).
Legislation cited in [3.4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Electronic Transactions Act 2000 cl 2.

JusticeLink eServices is an electronic document lodgment system available to legal practitioners and litigant organisations. It provides for electronic lodgment of up to 100 court documents at a time and for tracking of case activity online. Documents can be lodged and viewed outside Registry opening hours and immediate return of sealed documents is available. A list of the documents currently available for electronic lodgment is available on the Forms page for JusticeLink eServices on the Lawlink NSW website: http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/ lawlink/eservices/ll_eservices.nsf/pages/eservices_forms .

JusticeLink has been established under cl 2 of Sch 1 of the Electronic Transactions Act 2000. Pursuant to cl 3 of Sch 1, JusticeLink is authorised to be used by the Supreme Court, District Court, Local Court and the Court of Criminal Appeal: see Electronic Transactions (ECM Courts) Order 2005, esp Cols 1 and 2 of Sch 1 for the authorised use of JusticeLink in the various NSW courts.
Registered users can lodge court documents and pay the relevant filing fees online. Remote access is available for the following:
Sealed documents
Information about case initiation
Court results
Listings
Subpoenaed items
Exhibits.
JusticeLink eService generates an electronic record within the Registry, which is used as the formal court record of the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 3.4A] r 3.4A Written record to be kept of direction to e-file document

leg:heading.title: Written record to be kept of direction to e-file document

p.text: A person who directs that a document be filed as referred to in rule 3.4(2)(b) must make a written record of the fact that he or she has given such a direction.
If the person by whom the direction was given is a legal practitioner, the legal practitioner is taken:
to have affirmed to the court that he or she has given the direction, and
to have undertaken to the court that, if the court so directs, he or she will produce to the court the written record referred to in subrule (1).

If the person by whom the direction was given is a person who, pursuant to rule 4.4(1)(b) or 4.4(3) , is authorised to sign documents on behalf of a party in proceedings in the Local Court, that person is taken:
to have affirmed to the court that he or she has given the direction, and
to have undertaken to the court that, if the court so directs, he or she will produce to the court the written record referred to in subrule (1).
[subrule (2A) insrt Amendment 26 of 2009 Sch 1[2], effective 8 May 2009 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]

If in any proceedings in which a document has been filed as referred to in rule 3.4(2)(b) the court directs production of the written record referred to in subrule (1), it may also stay the proceedings until the record is produced.
[subrule (2B) insrt Amendment 26 of 2009 Sch 1[2], effective 8 May 2009]
A written direction for the purposes of rule 3.4(2)(b) is taken to be a written record for the purposes of this rule.
[r 3.4A insrt Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 30 September 2005]
This rule applies to an affidavit that is filed in the court by means of the
ECM system.
In the case of an affidavit filed by a legal practitioner, the legal practitioner is taken:
to have affirmed to the court that he or she has possession of the original affidavit, and
to have undertaken to the court that, if the court so directs, he or she will file the original affidavit in accordance with the court’s directions.
In the case of an affidavit filed otherwise than by a legal practitioner, the original affidavit must be filed in the court:
if a practice note so requires or the court so directs, and
if so required or directed, within the time limited by the relevant practice note or direction.
Any document referred to in an affidavit that cannot be filed by means of the ECM system is taken to be an exhibit, and not an annexure, regardless of the terms of the affidavit.

This rule applies to a will that is required to be filed in the court together with an application for probate of the will, or for administration of a person’s estate with the will annexed, if the application is, but the will is not, filed by means of the ECM system.
A will to which this rule applies must be filed in the court:
at least 2 days before the date of the next hearing in the proceedings in which the will is intended to be used, or
within 7 days after the date on which the application is filed by means of the ECM system, or
within such earlier time as the court may by order direct, whichever first occurs.
If the application is filed by a legal practitioner, the legal practitioner is taken:
to have affirmed to the court that he or she has possession of the will, and
to have undertaken to the court that, if the court so directs, he or she will file the will in accordance with the court’s directions.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 3.7] r 3.7 Electronic issuing of a document

p.text: The court may, by means of the ECM system, issue a document to any party who is a registered user for the proceedings.
The date and time at which the document was issued must be set out in the document.

When issued by means of the ECM system, a document that is required to be signed by a person is taken to have been duly authenticated for the purposes of clause 5 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000 if the person’s name is printed where his or her signature would otherwise appear.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 22 of 2008 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 8 August 2008 ; am Amendment 38 of 2010 s 3(3), effective 15 October 2010]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 3.8] r 3.8 Electronic service of a document

p.text: A party to any proceedings before the court may use electronic mail to serve a document on any other party to the proceedings, whether by means of the ECM system or otherwise, but only with the consent of the other party.
Legislation cited in [3.8.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Electronic Transactions Act 2000 cl 13 Sch 1.
See also Electronic Transactions Act 2000, cl 13 Sch 1 .
Consent to service by electronic mail may be given by including an electronic address for service in a notice of appearance: see Practice Note SC Gen 7 para 25.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 3.9] r r 3.9 Use of ECM system in business conducted in the absence of the public

leg:heading.title: Use of ECM system in business conducted in the absence of the public

p.text: Any business that, pursuant to section 71 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005, may be conducted in the absence of the public may be conducted by electronic communication sent and received by means of the ECM system, as provided by clause 9 of Schedule 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000.
[subr (1) am Amendment 38 of 2010 s 3(4), effective 15 October 2010]
A legal practitioner who is a registered user for any proceedings may participate in any such business:
directly (the legal practitioner sends a communication in his or her own name), or
indirectly (someone authorised by the legal practitioner sends a communication in the legal practitioner’s name).
[subr (2) insrt Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch1[3], effective 30 September 2005]

A legal practitioner who authorises someone else to send a communication, as referred to in subrule (2)(b), is taken to have affirmed to the court that he or she has actual knowledge of the contents of the communication.
[subr (3) insrt Amendment 3 of 2005 r 2 and Sch1[3], effective 30 September 2005]
Legislation cited in [3.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 71.
(NSW) Electronic Transactions Act 2000 cl 9 of Sch 1.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 3.3, r 3.9.

CPA s 71 permits a number of different types of proceedings to be conducted in the absence of the public. These include non-contentious proceedings, those not involving any personal appearance, guardianship proceedings and interlocutory proceedings (except to the extent they involve a witness giving oral evidence). The present rule, together with cl 9 of Sch 1 to the Electronic Transactions Act 2000 provides a mechanism to establish procedures to conduct those types of proceedings by electronic communication — in an “online court”. In addition, electronic filing has been introduced in the Corporations and Possession Lists in the Supreme Court and in the “online court” procedures being introduced into cases selected by judicial officers.
Practice Note SC Gen 12 sets out a protocol for the conduct of an online court. The essential features of the protocol include the following:

Online court availability is restricted to legal practitioners who are registered users for the purposes of UCPR r 3.9 . Registration forms are available at http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/eservices/ll_eservices.nsf/vwFiles/Application_ form_new_user.doc/$file/Application_form_new_user.doc . Completed forms should be emailed to justicelinksupport@agd.nsw.gov.au .
An online court can only be initiated by a judicial officer, although a legal practitioner may request initiation.
A judicial officer may order that all directions hearings for a particular matter be conducted via the online court.

Online court participants are allocated unique user identification code(s) and passwords. When a user-id is used to send messages and documents to an online court, the person to who that user-id was allocated will be deemed by the judicial officer presiding over the online court, to be the person who sent the messages and documents and is responsible for their contents.
Documents may be sent to, but cannot be filed in, an online court.
Documents sent to an online court must be in an “unlocked” (ie editable) PDF format.

See Koompahtoo Local Aboriginal Land Council v KLALC Property & Investments Pty Ltd (No 2) [2006] NSWSC 169; BC200602004 at [10] and Hill v W & F Lechner Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 440; BC200603298 at [3] for form of orders establishing ecmCourt for the purpose of directions hearings. See also Hill v W & F Lechner Pty Ltd [2006] NSWSC 440; BC200603298 at [11], [12] for orders compelling registration of legal representatives using the ecmCourt under UCPR r 3.3 and possible cost consequences of failure to do so.
